title: Ronnie O’Sullivan refuses to commit to next two Home Nations events
text:
Ronnie O’Sullivan has not committed to the Northern Ireland Open just yet (Picture: VCG via Getty Images)

Ronnie O’Sullivan is not committing to either the Northern Ireland or Scottish Open just yet, for differing reasons.

The Rocket played his first tournament on UK soil this season at the English Open last week, but suffered a shock defeat in the last 16 to Mei Xiwen.

The Crawley event is the first of three in the Home Nations Series, which goes to Belfast in November, Glasgow in December and finishes in Cardiff in February.

O’Sullivan has had mixed results in the four tournaments in recent years, winning just one of the 13 editions since the Home Nations Series was brought in in 2016.

The 43-year-old reached the final of the Northern Ireland Open last year, losing out to Judd Trump, and expects to be back in Belfast next month, but will not confirm his entry.

‘Yeah probably,’ the Rocket told Eurosport on his plans to enter Northern Ireland. ‘It depends how I do in China, if I do well there I can afford to have a few days off.’

O’Sullivan is something of a surprise entry at the World Open in Yushan, travelling to China this week to compete in the event which starts next Monday.

The five-time world champion has declared his plans to play more of the tournaments in Asia, something he has not done in recent years, failing to enter the World Open since it moved to China in 2012.

The Scottish Open in December may not be impacted by the Rocket’s performances elsewhere but instead by his dislike of the venue in Glasgow.

The tournament has been held at the Emirates Arena since it returned to the calendar in 2016 and the Rocket is not a fan of the setting.

‘If it’s a train journey for four or five hours I probably swerve it,’ O’Sullivan said after his first round win at the English Open. ‘I’ll probably try and swerve Scotland [Scottish Open], I love Glasgow but where they put it, it’s not a great place.

‘That’s why I’m playing more China events next, they have good venues, proper tournaments, over here they’re struggling for cash, I think.

‘Over in China they’ve got much more resources financially, they can put a better event on.’

O’Sullivan will be in action on Monday 28 October in the qualifying round of the World Open against Dominic Dale.
